posts.name: bharrison6
posts.cooked:
Our FRC team (3843) is having an intermittent error that stops our robot code in the middle of enable, disabling it automatically. This happens occasionally during our test driving runs. We can’t seem to find any correctable errors with stacktrace from the log file and don’t know where or how to fix the random loss of robot code. We have noticed spikes in roborio cpu% during our run.

The error message we have is below. ERROR  1  The startCompetition() method (or methods called by it) should have handled the exception above.  edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotBase.runRobot(RobotBase.java:440)    	at frc.robot.Main.main(Main.java:27)  	at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotBase.startRobot(RobotBase.java:510)  	at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotBase.runRobot(RobotBase.java:419)  	at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.TimedRobot.startCompetition(TimedRobot.java:133)  	at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.IterativeRobotBase.loopFunc(IterativeRobotBase.java:403)  	at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.smartdashboard.SmartDashboard.updateValues(SmartDashboard.java:517)  	at edu.wpi.first.util.sendable.SendableRegistry.update(SendableRegistry.java:485)  	at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.smartdashboard.SendableBuilderImpl.update(SendableBuilderImpl.java:185)  	at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.smartdashboard.SendableBuilderImpl$Property.update(SendableBuilderImpl.java:90)  	at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.smartdashboard.SendableBuilderImpl.lambda$addStringArrayProperty$18(SendableBuilderImpl.java:658)  	at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Alert$SendableAlerts.lambda$initSendable$4(Alert.java:209)  	at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Alert$SendableAlerts.getStrings(Alert.java:202)  	at java.base/java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline.toArray(Unknown Source)  	at java.base/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.evaluateToArrayNode(Unknown Source)  	at java.base/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.evaluate(Unknown Source)  	at java.base/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.wrapAndCopyInto(Unknown Source)  	at java.base/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.copyInto(Unknown Source)  	at java.base/java.util.stream.Sink$ChainedReference.end(Unknown Source)  	at java.base/java.util.stream.Nodes$FixedNodeBuilder.end(Unknown Source) Warning  1  The robot program quit unexpectedly. This is usually due to a code error. The above stacktrace can help determine where the error occurred. See Reading Stacktraces — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation for more information.  edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotBase.runRobot(RobotBase.java:433)  Error at java.base/java.util.stream.Nodes$FixedNodeBuilder.end(Unknown Source): Unhandled exception: java.lang.IllegalStateException: End size 0 is less than fixed size 1 ERROR  1  Unhandled exception: java.lang.IllegalStateException: End size 0 is less than fixed size 1  java.base/java.util.stream.Nodes$FixedNodeBuilder.end(Unknown Source)

This is our current code:

Contribute to FRC-Team-3843/FRC-2025 development by creating an account on GitHub.

If you have any questions or need more info, please let us know.

posts.name: BillDunlap
posts.cooked:
bharrison6:

ERROR 1 The startCompetition() method (or methods called by it) should have handled the exception above. edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotBase.runRobot(RobotBase.java:440) at

Did the log above this point describe an exception, along with a traceback? (You only showed stuff below this message.)

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: This is most likely caused by calling Alert from a secondary thread.  Alert is not thread-safe.  If you’re using akit, this can be caused by calling akit logging functions from a secondary thread.

posts.name: bharrison6
posts.cooked: Nothing above this that is out of the ordinary.

posts.name: bharrison6
posts.cooked: That I am aware of we have not called alert anywhere in our code, though we are using yagsl. Could it be that yagsl is causing the issue?
It seems that your YAGSL vendor dep is out of date. Have you tried updating it and seeing if that fixes the issue? (The most recent version seems to be 2025.7.2)

posts.name: bharrison6
posts.cooked:
We updated it. Weird because it wouldn’t update with update all or hitting update button. I had to remove the library and reinstall to update. It’s why it’s out of date because we update libraries every week or so.

Hopefully that is the problem but out of curiosity could this be caused by a CAN issue? We are definitely out of spec on our CAN stubs.

posts.name: Ben Malito
posts.cooked:
I think if this were caused by a CAN issue, you would be able to see very high CAN bus usage on Driverstation. If you still have the logs from when this issue was happening, you might try to search for any CAN bus related messages within the log.

Are you having loop overruns? If your robot code overruns the 20ms CommandScheduler loop, that can cause your code to crash mid-practice/mid-match.

posts.name: bharrison6
posts.cooked: Just an update. We updated all of our code and never had another issue. Maybe something in the update fixed the code or maybe we still have an issue but haven’t triggered it again. It was very infrequent. Thanks to all who helped!
